name: Flood/Deluge Myths
definition: The Flood Myth represents one of the most widespread archetypal narratives in world mythology - the story of a great deluge sent by divine powers to cleanse or destroy the world, with a select few survivors preserved to begin humanity anew. This archetype appears independently in virtually every major culture: the Babylonian epic of Utnapishtim, the Hebrew account of Noah, the Greek story of Deucalion, the Hindu tale of Manu, and flood narratives from China, Mesoamerica, Australia, and countless other traditions. The flood represents divine judgment, cosmic reset, and the opportunity for renewal. As an archetype, it addresses fundamental human concerns about mortality, divine justice, the fragility of civilization, and the possibility of starting fresh. The survivor figure embodies righteousness, obedience to divine will, and the preservation of knowledge and life across catastrophic transition.

crossCulturalComparisons.example: Utnapishtim in the Epic of Gilgamesh
crossCulturalComparisons.details: Oldest recorded flood narrative; gods send flood due to human noise; Ea warns Utnapishtim to build boat
God sends flood due to human wickedness; Noah finds favor; covenant established with rainbow sign
Zeus floods earth to punish impiety; couple survives in chest; repopulates by throwing stones
Manu saves small fish (Vishnu's avatar); fish warns of flood; Manu builds boat, preserves Vedas
Massive floods controlled by Yu the Great; emphasis on engineering and civilization-building
World destroyed by flood at end of Fourth Sun era; people become fish

examples.description: Son of Prometheus who survived Zeus's flood with wife Pyrrha

examples.name: Manu

examples.name: Nuh
examples.description: Prophet who preached for 950 years before the flood came

characteristics: Universal or near-universal: appears across unconnected cultures
Catastrophic: represents total or near-total destruction
Divine agency: flood sent by god(s) for specific purpose
Selective survival: righteous or chosen individuals preserved
Reset narrative: world is cleansed and begins anew
Etiological: often explains current world order or covenant
Warning element: advance notice given to the worthy
Sacrificial conclusion: thanks or worship after survival
